title: I received a lien on my bank account for fees I owed from criminal court from 2011 in San Diego, can I have them removed?
question: I just received a lien on my bank account for fees I owed from criminal court back in 2011 that I never have been able to pay off. I am a single mother of 3 living in California without the help of government assistance. I have terrible credit & owe even banks money because I cannot get ahead. They have tried garnishing my wages but have not been successful since I fall below the threshold. They HAVE taken from my taxes- & the money they have taken is NEVER reflected in subsequent bills nor have I received a receipt. I have not worked since graduating college & moving in 2017. The money they are asking for is $4,000 + but I have paid off one of the attorney's fees so it should be less. I want to challenge these fees & know why they have never reflected the payments I did make & ask for a reduction. I am upset is because $1000 of it is for restitution to my daughter... whom I still have joint custody of who also happens to live in Boston, MA since 2012. I'd be paying myself. My husband says he has not received a dime of the money I had been paying. I have been off of probation since 2014 I have paid for and completed all my classes and have outside of this never been in trouble.
answers:
It seems you have received notice of a levy on your bank account. I'm sorry that this has happened.

The creditor is entitled to levy on a judgment. You can file a Claim of Exemption and submit it to the Sheriff of the County where the levy is issued, and a hearing may be set in your county of residence. That could get you some of the money back.

Another option is possibly filing a bankruptcy petition, which will temporarily stop collection activity; and it's possible you could get most of that levied money back, but whether the underlying debt itself will ultimately be discharged in the bankruptcy case depends on whether it is owed to the criminal court as reimbursement for costs, or is a fine, as punishment, as part of the sentence you received.

If the money owed is reimbursement for costs, a bankruptcy petition would discharge the debt.

However, if the money owed is part of a criminal fine, that part would not be discharged by the bankruptcy and you would still owe the money.
